description: A course on statistical methods for social scientists, applying the general linear model (GLM. Students learn the logic and assumptions underlying the GLM and complete exercises that apply linear modeling techniques using the Stata statistical package to "real-world" data. Issues covered include the logic of statistical modeling, efficient estimation (i.e. statistical precision), specification errors (i.e. what happens when you make incorrect assumptions about how the world works), analyzing group differences with discrete (qualitative) variables (e.g. looking at differences in social processes by gender, or race), representing social processes with multiple equations ("path analysis"), and nonlinear relationships in linear models.
name: QUANT METHODS II

values.comments:
This class analyzes the statistical methods for social scientists by using the general linear model.  Students learn about the assumptions and logic behind the GLM. Students also learn about topics such as statistical modeling, efficient estimation, and nonlinear relationships in linear models. 
Students felt that the material in the class was very interesting however also very “challenging.” Student’s overall commented on the high quality of material learned. Students considered the class to be a “very well constructed course.”
Students raved about the teaching style of Dr. Allison.  Many students felt that he was an “excellent teacher” and “one of the best professors I have ever had.”  Students enjoyed how he “communicates the course content so clearly.”
This class is taken mostly by upperclassman to fulfill major or sector requirements.
